Authors:
Xingtan Zhang, Lanping Chen, Qing Zhang, Qian Zhao, Haibao
Tang, Kai Wang, Qingyi Yu, Ray Ming, Jisen Zhang
Title:
Comparative genomics analysis of sucrose phosphate synthase
(SPS) gene family between S. officinarum and S. spontaneum
Keywords:
Sugarcane, S. officinarum , S. spontaneum , SPS gene,
polyploidy, BAC
Abstract:
Background: Sucrose phosphate synthase (SPS) genes play
vital roles in sucrose production across various plant species. Modern
sugarcane cultivar derived from the hybridization between high sugar
content S. officinarum and high stress tolerance specie S. spontaneum,
leading to one of the most complex genomes among all crops. The genomics
of sugarcane SPS is still under-studied despite its profound impact on
the sugar yield. Results: In this study, 8 and 6 genomic sequences for
SPS family members were identified from the BAC libraries of S.
officinarum and S. spontaneum, respectively. Frequent sequence
substitutions and structural variations were observed in SPS homologs as
well as allelic haplotypes. These variations or mutations may influence
the functions of SPSs, such as F6P binding activity. Phylogenetic
analysis showed that sugarcane SPS genes were clustered into four
sub-families (A to D) and SPSD members were newly evolved in the lineage
of Poaceae species. SPSD1 and SPSD2 were further suggested to be recent
duplication genes emerged from SPSA clade. TE insertions were observed
in SPSC before and after the divergence of the two sugarcane species.
Molecular evolution analysis based on Ka/Ks ratios suggested that
polyploidy reduced selection pressure of SPS genes in Saccharum. In
addition, RNA-seq data uncovers the different expression patterns of SPS
gene family between S. officinarum and S.spontaneum, suggesting that
possibly SPSA and SPSB are responsible for the fundamental difference of
sugar yield at different stages. Conclusions: Our research presents
comprehensive analysis of SPS genes in S. officinarum and S.spontaneum.
These results provide valuable information for further functional
studies of multiple SPS gene members in sugarcanes.
